entry.title: Combined summary - Continuing the discussion about noinput / anyprevout
entry.summary: The Lightning-dev mailing list recently discussed the usefulness of noinput/anyprevoutanyscript/anyprevout and its advantages for off-chain protocol designs, particularly eltoo. Some concerns were raised about potential misuse or abuse of rebindable transactions, but these concerns can be addressed through classification. The downsides of chaperone signatures outweigh their advantages, as they require extra code complexity and are not necessary for opt-in functionality. Output tagging also presents issues with anonymity for taproot transactions.It was suggested that BIP-118 and bip-anyprevout be merged, but belt-and-suspender protections like chaperone signatures and tagged outputs should not be part of the initial specification. Efforts like descriptors can help ensure best practices when working with complex scripts without adding extra complexity to the consensus layer of bitcoin. The email thread also discusses the possible use of Decker-Russell-Osuntokun, a transaction building technique used in off-chain payment networks, and suggests merging BIP-118 and bip-anyprevout.During a Bitcoin development meeting, several proposals were discussed, including `sighash_noinput` and `bip-anyprevout`. There are concerns about the potential risks and downsides of `sighash_noinput`, such as the possibility for address reuse leading to wallet drain. To address this issue, an alternative proposal was presented by ZmnSCPxj, suggesting the creation of a new opcode called `OP_CHECKSIG_WITHOUT_INPUT`. The wider community's feedback is being sought on the usefulness of these proposals and the potential downsides of output tagging and chaperone signatures.Bitcoin developer Christian Decker is seeking feedback on proposals related to Taproot, a privacy and scalability-focused upgrade to the Bitcoin protocol. The proposals include noinput/ anyprevoutanyscript/ anyprevout, chaperone signatures, and output tagging which could enhance privacy and reduce transaction fees but may also lead to fund loss or harm fungibility. A proposal has been made to create a new opcode called `OP_CHECKSIG_WITHOUT_INPUT` instead of using `SIGHASH_NOINPUT`.Christian Decker and AJ discuss the use of opt-in via pubkey prefix to avoid losing funds while handling additional coins sent to the same address. The opt-in feature at the tapscript level guarantees that an address can never be signed for with an anyprevout signature, which prevents double-spending/malleability risks. The scheme is extendable to opt into all sighash flags, allowing the pubkey prefix to act as a mask for the sighash flags and fail verification if they do not match.The conversation also emphasizes the need for an effective demonstration of theoretical attacks in a laboratory setting to ensure that all possible corner cases are handled. Establishing a public testnet where people can demo every weird noinput/anyprevout case would be valuable in working out whether extra code/tagging/whatever is needed to prevent fake exchanges/merchants from losing money.Output tagging is deemed unnecessary when receiving funds spent via an anyprevout signature, and there is no need for users to mark anyprevout spends as "tainted" to wait for more confirmations than normal before considering those funds safe. Christian Decker likes the option of hidden nature of the opt-in via pubkey prefix, according to Towns' proposal. If output tagging and the like aren't necessary, it would be good evidence that they are not needed. Conversely, if they are required, it gives an opportunity to see how they work and whether they provide any meaningful protection.
